metadata.case_name: Tinnevelli-Tuticorin Electric Supply Co., Ltd. v. Their Workmen

facts.text: The appellant is an electric supply undertaking carrying on business as a licensee under the State Government of Madras subject to the Indian Electricity Act, 1910 and the Electricity Supply Act, 1948.
The appellant buys electric supply from State Hydro-electric Projects and supplies it to consumers in areas around Tinnevelli and Tuticorin Municipalities.

Appellant's workmen (respondents) made demands for terms of employment, leading to industrial dispute referred by Madras Government to Industrial Tribunal at Madurai under s.10(1)(c) of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, including claim for additional bonus for 1952.
Appellant voluntarily paid two months basic wages as bonus, but respondents claimed additional bonus.
Industrial Tribunal rejected appellant's contention that no bonus admissible outside Act and awarded two months basic wages additional bonus on March 4, 1955.
Appellant appealed to Labour Appellate Tribunal (Appeal No. 56 of 1955), contending no additional bonus without excess clear profits over reasonable return.
Labour Appellate Tribunal grouped appeals raising same issue before fuller bench of five members due to conflicting decisions.
Fuller bench held Full Bench formula applies to electricity concerns, remanded appeals including appellant's.
Industrial Tribunal at Madras (after Madurai abolished) applied Full Bench formula and awarded two months additional bonus on April 9, 1956.
Appellant appealed (Appeal Madras No. 96 of 1956), tribunal rectified calculation error and awarded one month's basic wage additional bonus on September 29, 1956.
Appellant filed appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Full Bench formula can and should be applied in adjudicating claim for bonus by employees of electricity supply undertakings governed by the Electricity Supply Act, 1948, or whether bonus can only be from excess clear profits over reasonable return under the Act.

Whether bonus paid to employees is included under paragraph 17(2)(b)(xi) of the Sixth Schedule as 'other expenses admissible under the law for the time being in force in the assessment of Indian Income-tax and arising from and ancillary or incidental to the business of electricity supply'.

petitioner_arguments.text: No claim for bonus admissible outside provisions of Electricity Supply Act, 1948; scheme restricts profits to reasonable return; bonus only from excess clear profits over reasonable return; quantum as 1/4th of such excess.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Electricity Supply Act, 1948 (Sixth Schedule); Indian Electricity Act, 1910

petitioner_arguments.text: Bonus not admissible under para 17(2)(b)(xi) Sixth Schedule as not arising from or ancillary/incidental to electricity supply business.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Electricity Supply Act, 1948 Sixth Schedule para 17(2)(b)(xi)

petitioner_arguments.text: Claim for rehabilitation using factor 2-7 for pre-1945 assets and estimated life from Schedule without deducting expired life.
Triple shift allowance for all electric plant and machinery under Income-tax Rule 8 Entry IIIE(1).

respondent_arguments.text: Fairly conceded before Labour Appellate Tribunal that income-tax at seven annas in rupee, contingency reserve Rs.6,047, normal statutory depreciation Rs.99,038 to be allowed.
Appellant's cables and wires fall under IIIC(4) and (5) of Income-tax Rules, no extra shift allowance (N.E.S.A.).

court_reasoning.text: Fields covered by Full Bench formula (social justice, sharing profits to bridge living wage gap) and Act (regulating rates, reasonable return for consumers and undertakings) are different; no conflict; use commercial accounts/profit & loss, not Act's working-sheet.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act does not deal with wages or bonus; industrial adjudication principles apply independently.

court_reasoning.text: Bonus admissible under para 17(2)(b)(xi) as expense under Income-tax Act and ancillary/incidental to business; later amendment cl.xiii clarifies original intent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Contributions to Provident Fund similarly treated.

court_reasoning.text: No evidence led for rehabilitation claim; factor 2-7 and undeducted asset life unjustified.
No extra shift depreciation for cables/wires; no proof claimed/admitted before income-tax authorities; separate provisions in IIIC(4),(5).

holdings.text: Full Bench formula applies to bonus claims against electricity supply undertakings.
Bonus is admissible expenditure under Sixth Schedule para 17(2)(b)(xi).

precedents_cited.case_name: U. P. Electricity Supply Co. Ltd. Ors. v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Fuller bench decision on Full Bench formula applicability and statutory depreciation extent.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sree Meenakshi Mills Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Confirmed fuller bench on normal income-tax depreciation only (not initial/additional).

precedents_cited.case_name: Baroda Borough Municipality v. Its Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Municipal Act provisions do not bar bonus claims under Industrial Disputes Act.

statutes_cited.name: Electricity (Supply) Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Regulates licensees' charges, clear profit, reasonable return; bonus admissible as expense.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld Labour Appellate Tribunal's decision applying Full Bench formula, holding it applicable to electricity undertakings and bonus admissible under Act; rejected appellant's claims on rehabilitation and extra shift allowance for lack of evidence; affirmed one month's additional bonus.
outcome.relief_granted: One month's basic wages additional bonus to respondents upheld.

key_quotes.text: "the fields covered by the Full Bench formula and by the provisions of the Act are entirely different."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning distinguishing Act from bonus adjudication.

key_quotes.text: "Can it be said that in fixing the wage structure as between an electricity undertaking and its employees considerations of social justice would be irrelevant?"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Emphasizes social justice in wage/bonus independent of Act.

key_quotes.text: "the insertion of this clause can be more reasonably explained on the assumption that the Legislature has thereby clarified its original intention."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: On bonus as admissible expense under Sixth Schedule.
